clusters.title: Policy Goals
clusters.description: Inflation rates in the U.S. have shown fluctuations, with the consumer price index (CPI) rising at an annual rate of 2.5% in August, down from 2.9% in July. The Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) aims for a 2% inflation target, while the current U.S. inflation rate stands at 2.8% as of February 2025. Policymakers continue to focus on bringing inflation down to their medium-term target.

The period from 1931 to 1932 marked the greatest deflation in U.S. history at more than 10 percent.
From 1945 to 1949, American households purchased 20 million refrigerators.
From 1945 to 1949, American households purchased 21.4 million cars.
From 1945 to 1949, American households purchased 5.5 million stoves.
Overall inflation shot up 10.5 percent during the first “oil shock” (December 1972 - December 1974).
The price of energy increased 19.3 percent during the first “oil shock” (December 1972 - December 1974).
The price of food increased 16.1 percent during the first “oil shock” (December 1972 - December 1974).
Oil prices jumped from a low of $35.59 a barrel to a high of $127.77 a barrel in 2008. The difference in price was $92.18 per barrel.
Americans went from paying less than $2 a gallon to a high of $4.14 a gallon in July 2008.

Various sectors, including energy and food, experienced substantial inflation spikes, with energy inflation reaching 41.6% in 2022 and food prices increasing by 11.4% during the same period.

all_fact_content: Overall inflation shot up 10.5 percent during the first “oil shock” (December 1972 - December 1974).
The price of energy increased 19.3 percent during the first “oil shock” (December 1972 - December 1974).
The price of food increased 16.1 percent during the first “oil shock” (December 1972 - December 1974).
From 1945 to 1949, American households purchased 20 million refrigerators.
From 1945 to 1949, American households purchased 21.4 million cars.
From 1945 to 1949, American households purchased 5.5 million stoves.
The largest single-year price increase during the post-World War I era was 23.7 percent from June 1919 to June 1920.
Prices surged more than 80 percent from late 1916 to mid-1920.
Prices fell more than 15 percent in 1921.
The period from 1931 to 1932 marked the greatest deflation in U.S. history at more than 10 percent.
Crude oil went from a low of $16.04 a barrel in 1989 to a high of $32.88 a barrel in 1990.
Oil prices jumped from a low of $35.59 a barrel to a high of $127.77 a barrel in 2008. The difference in price was $92.18 per barrel.
Americans went from paying less than $2 a gallon to a high of $4.14 a gallon in July 2008.

related_facts.fact_group_content: 47 percent felt very stressed by inflation.
More than 60 percent were very concerned about future, short-term inflation.
Households with incomes ranging from $25,000 to $35,000 were about 19.3 percentage points more likely to be very stressed by inflation than households with incomes in the $75,000 to $100,000 range.
Households earning $250,000 or more were over 25 percentage points less likely to find recent inflation very stressful.
57.2 percent of Hispanics reported inflation stress.
53.7 percent of Blacks reported inflation stress.
43.6 percent of whites reported inflation stress.
38.6 percent of Asians reported inflation stress.
56.5 percent of those paying rent were very stressed by high inflation.
43.4 percent of homeowners with a mortgage were very stressed by high inflation.
39.3 percent of owners without a mortgage were very stressed by high inflation.
Renters are on average 3.1 percentage points more likely to feel very stressed by inflation than owner occupants with a mortgage.
Homeowners without a mortgage were 3.3 percentage points less likely than renters to be very stressed by inflation.
An extra adult increases the chances of high inflation stress by 2 percentage points.
An extra child raises inflation stress by 4.2 percentage points.
62% of Americans say inflation is a very big problem in 2023.
70% of Americans said inflation was a very big problem in 2022.
The perceived importance of inflation as a very big problem decreased from 70% in 2022 to 62% in 2023.
60% of Americans say bipartisan cooperation is a very big problem.
75% of voters said inflation had caused them moderate or severe hardship over the past year.
62% of Americans describe inflation as a very big problem.

clusters.title: Public Concerns
clusters.description: Inflation remains a significant concern for Americans, with 62% identifying it as a major issue in 2023, down from 70% in 2022. The impact of inflation varies across demographics, with lower-income households and renters experiencing higher stress levels. Additionally, inflation has caused moderate to severe hardship for 75% of voters over the past year.

clusters.title: Income Challenges
clusters.description: From 2019 to 2023, the average annual growth of real adjusted income after transfers and taxes was 2.1%, while real adjusted market income grew by 2.6%. Despite these increases, the purchasing power of middle-income households was significantly impacted by inflation, reducing their annual income by approximately $3,000. The price of consumption bundles for middle-income households rose at an average annual rate of 4.5%, further affecting their financial stability.

clusters.title: CPI Variations
clusters.description: The Consumer Price Index (CPI) has seen notable shifts, with the shelter index rising by 0.3% and accounting for nearly half of the all items index. Energy and food indices also experienced increases, while gasoline prices fell. Historically, food and apparel once dominated the CPI weight, but now they represent a smaller portion. Medical care services have seen a significant rise, and food prices at grocery stores surged over a year.

clusters.title: CPI Influence
clusters.description: The Consumer Price Index (CPI) significantly influences the financial well-being of a vast number of individuals in the United States. It directly affects the incomes of nearly 80 million people, including Social Security beneficiaries, military and federal retirees, and food stamp recipients. Additionally, over 2 million workers have their collective bargaining agreements tied to the CPI, highlighting its widespread economic impact.

clusters.title: Government Debt
clusters.description: The government has engaged in significant financial activities, including $5 trillion in COVID-related deficits and borrowing $5 trillion from 2021 to 2023. The Federal Reserve purchased $3 trillion of this new debt. Additionally, the Inflation Reduction Act (IRA) has allocated substantial funds, such as $11.7 billion for the Loan Programs Office and $5 billion for the EIR Program, with a total loan cap of $250 billion.

clusters.title: Historical Fluctuations
clusters.description: The cluster highlights significant price changes in the U.S. over various periods, including post-World War I inflation, the deflation of the early 1930s, and the impact of oil shocks. Notable events include a 23.7% price increase from 1919 to 1920, a dramatic deflation in 1931-1932, and substantial price hikes during the 1970s oil crisis. Additionally, the cluster notes the surge in oil prices in 2008, reflecting broader economic pressures.

Oil prices jumped from $35.59 to $127.77 a barrel in 2008

clusters.title: Inflation Peaks
clusters.description: The U.S. experienced significant inflation peaks in the 20th century, with the highest recorded between March 1979 and March 1980 at 14.8%, marking the most severe inflation since World War II. Other notable periods include a 20.1% increase from March 1946 to March 1947 and a 6.8% rise from 1950 to 1951. The Volcker-era inflation peak in March 1980 was 14.8%, or 11.6% when adjusted for OER.

article.title: Inflation: 6 Times Americans Felt the Pinch

facts.fact_content: Oil prices jumped from a low of $35.59 a barrel to a high of $127.77 a barrel in 2008. The difference in price was $92.18 per barrel.
Americans went from paying less than $2 a gallon to a high of $4.14 a gallon in July 2008.
Crude oil went from a low of $16.04 a barrel in 1989 to a high of $32.88 a barrel in 1990.
The price of food increased 16.1 percent during the first “oil shock” (December 1972 - December 1974).
The price of energy increased 19.3 percent during the first “oil shock” (December 1972 - December 1974).
Food prices jumped 11.4 percent at the grocery store from June 2021 to June 2022.
Gasoline was down 1%.
The CPI grew 8.6% in the twelve months ending in May.
Traders expect the CPI rate to grow to around 9% over the next four months.
The current inflation rate is 2.8%.
